1.text: After this hath Job opened his mouth, and revileth his day.

3.text: Let the day perish in which I am born, And the night that hath said: ‘A man-child hath been conceived.’

4.text: That day—let it be darkness, Let not God require it from above, Nor let light shine upon it.

5.text: Let darkness and death-shade redeem it, Let a cloud tabernacle upon it, Let them terrify it as the most bitter of days.

6.text: That night—let thick darkness take it, Let it not be united to days of the year, Into the number of months let it not come.

7.text: Lo! that night—let it be gloomy, Let no singing come into it.

8.text: Let the cursers of day mark it, Who are ready to wake up Leviathan.

9.text: Let the stars of its twilight be dark, Let it wait for light, and there is none, And let it not look on the eyelids of the dawn.

10.text: Because it hath not shut the doors Of the womb that was mine! And hide misery from mine eyes.

11.text: Why from the womb do I not die? From the belly I have come forth and gasp!

12.text: Wherefore have knees been before me? And what are breasts, that I suck?

13.text: For now, I have lain down, and am quiet, I have slept—then there is rest to me,

14.text: With kings and counsellors of earth, These building wastes for themselves.

15.text: Or with princes—they have gold, They are filling their houses with silver.

16.text: (Or as a hidden abortion I am not, As infants—they have not seen light.)

17.text: There the wicked have ceased troubling, And there rest do the wearied in power.

18.text: Together prisoners have been at ease, They have not heard the voice of an exactor,

19.text: Small and great are there the same. And a servant is free from his lord.

20.text: Why giveth He to the miserable light, and life to the bitter soul?

21.text: Who are waiting for death, and it is not, And they seek it above hid treasures.

22.text: Who are glad—unto joy, They rejoice when they find a grave.

23.text: To a man whose way hath been hidden, And whom God doth shut up?

24.text: For before my food, my sighing cometh, And poured out as waters are my roarings.

25.text: For a fear I feared and it meeteth me, And what I was afraid of doth come to me.

26.text: I was not safe—nor was I quiet—Nor was I at rest—and trouble cometh!
